newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel's Netanyahu to seek European support.
newsitem.headline: Israel's Netanyahu to seek European support.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu embarks on his first European diplomatic tour on Tuesday, seeking statements of support from Britain, France and Germany.

Since taking office in June, Netanyahu has made two visits to Israel's main ally, the United States, eliciting statements from President Bill Clinton that his right-wing government seeks to bolster peace with the Palestinians.
Now he thinks it is Europe's turn.

"Europe can play an important political role in the Middle East, for example, by confirming and affirming the principle...that we are moving and we all should move forward to peace," Netanyahu told reporters at a briefing last week.
In Germany last week, Palestinian President Yasser Arafat called for pressure on Netanyahu to honour Middle East peace deals signed by the previous Labour-led Israeli government.
"Frustration and desperation are quickly increasing," Arafat said. "This drags the region back to extremism, violence and terrorism. Enmity and war are appearing on the horizon."
Netanyahu opposes trading occupied Arab land for peace, the foundation of Middle East peace efforts launched at a conference in Madrid in 1991.

Citing security concerns, he has yet to carry out a long-delayed Israeli troop redeployment in the West Bank town of Hebron and has maintained a closure that bars most Palestinians from entering Israel.
But earlier this month Netanyahu held his first summit with Arafat, signalling acceptance of the Palestinian leader as a negotiating partner and helping to ensure a cordial welcome in world capitals.
Netanyahu kicks off his three-day tour in London, where he will meet Prime Minister John Major, opposition Labour party chief Tony Blair and former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.
He flies to Paris on Wednesday for talks with President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Alain Juppe before travelling to Bonn on Thursday to meet Chancellor Helmut Kohl.
Of the countries on Netanyahu's itinerary, France has the most high-profile role in Middle East diplomacy.

It participates, along with the United States, Syria, Israel and Lebanon, on a committee monitoring an accord that ended an Israeli military blitz in south Lebanon in April. Chirac is to visit the Middle East in late October.
Netanyahu's trip sidesteps a main Israeli diplomatic problem with the European Union -- a long-running dispute over whether foreign ministers should visit PLO headquarters in Jerusalem.

The prime minister will not be visiting Ireland, the Netherlands or Italy, whose "troika" of EU ministers had wanted to go to Orient House, a symbol of the PLO's desire to make East Jerusalem the capital of a future Palestinian state.
"The Palestinian side signed a solemn pledge not to have any government activity of the PA (Palestinian self-rule Authority) institutions in Jerusalem," Netanyahu said last week.
"I would find it astonishing that Europe would try to be more Palestinian than the Palestinians" by sending ministers to Orient House," he said.
Israel captured East Jerusalem in the 1967 Middle East war and regards all the city as its capital, a claim that has failed to win international recognition.
